text:
> oh, no, that’s not supposed to be possible
Okay, it’s possible that what’s happening is that there’s a global limit that has changed since when I first tested this; the original container now gets to 64KB now, so I’m thinking that’s what happened.  It is all consistently `64 KB` now.

elements.text: oh, no, that’s not supposed to be possible

Okay, it’s possible that what’s happening is that there’s a global limit that has changed since when I first tested this; the original container now gets to 64KB now, so I’m thinking that’s what happened.  It is all consistently
64 KB
now.

text: wait, but how?

1048576
buildworker@e9db32e19313:/buildworker$ M=0; while true; do dd if=/dev/zero bs=1k count=1 2>/dev/null;        M=$(($M+1)); echo -en "\r$M KB" 1>&2; done | sleep 999
64 KB^C
buildworker@e9db32e19313:/buildworker$ M=0; while true; do dd if=/dev/zero bs=1k count=1 2>/dev/null;        M=$(($M+1)); echo -en "\r$M KB" 1>&2; done | sleep 999
64 KB^C
buildworker@e9db32e19313:/buildworker$ exit

text: Can I get a summary of what's going on here? For some reason sometimes the pipe buffer limit is low?

elements.text: What is
cat /proc/sys/fs/pipe-max-size
inside the containers?
Can I get a summary of what's going on here? For some reason sometimes the pipe buffer limit is low?

text: Ah, there’s a linux parameter for this

elements.text: Ah, there’s a linux parameter for this

text: `/proc/sys/fs/pipe-user-pages-soft`

elements.text: /proc/sys/fs/pipe-user-pages-soft

text: You’re only allowed to have 1024 unrestricted pipes per user

elements.text: You’re only allowed to have 1024 unrestricted pipes per user

text: the rest will be restricted to one page

elements.text: the rest will be restricted to one page

text: the rest will be restricted to one page

elements.text: the rest will be restricted to one page
